bookinfo.title: Using WebDAV to Access the Database

section.title: Introducing WebDAV
section.para: eXist ships with a WebDAV interface. WebDAV makes it possible to manage database collections and documents just like directories and files in a file system. You can copy, move, delete, view or edit files with any application supporting the WebDAV protocol, including Windows Explorer, Mac OS X Finder, cadaver, KDE Konqueror, oXygen XML Editor, XML Spy, OpenOffice.org and many others (see "Compatibility" below).

While eXist has had WebDAV support since version 1.0b2, the new WebDAV implementation in version 1.4.1 brings improved WebDAV compatibility, thanks to its use of the excellent open-source Milton WebDAV API for Java.
In the default configuration the WebDAV server can be accessed via the URLs http://localhost:8080/exist/webdav/db/ and https://localhost:8443/exist/webdav/db/.

section.title: Compatibility
section.para: The Milton project maintains a detailed WebDAV client compatibility list that describes a "Recipe for broad client compatibility." In case of any problems please read this document. However, some preliminary points specific to eXist should be kept in mind:

listitem.para: eXist's Milton interface does not currently support HTTP Digest Authentication, in contrast to the original pre-Milton implementation.

The size of an XML document is presented as a multiple of 4096 bytes, which is eXist's internal pagesize (see conf.xml). The actual size on an XML document stored in the database can not be determined because the size depends on many factors, e.g. the applied serialization parameters.

It turns out that some WebDAV clients can not handle estimated sizes, cutting off the transfer prematurely. A workaround has been implemented to help some clients, but in some cases this doesn't seem to be sufficient. You may need to find a different WebDAV client or contact your WebDAV client's developer.

section.para: The Milton-based WebDAV interface has been successfully tested with: Windows Web Folders (Windows XP/7), AnyClient (cross-platform), Mac OS X Finder, Transmit (Mac OS X), davfs version 1.4.5 (Linux) and OpenOffice.org.
The following clients are reported to have issues: GVFS (Nautilus) and NetDrive.

section.title: Windows Web Folders
section.para: Out of the box, Windows (XP, 7) has some native support for the WebDAV protocol, but there are some well-known issues. Please consult the following articles in case of any problem.

note.para: Be aware that there are multiple versions of WebDAV Microsoft libraries (and different flavors of bugs). To avoid some frustration if the steps below don't work for you, Update Windows XP for Web Folders, or take more information about Web Folder Client (MSDAIPP.DLL) Versions and Issues.

Windows Vista and Windows 7 both restrict access to WebDAV servers that use Basic HTTP authentication on non-SSL connections. This restriction can be solved by changing a registry key. Read more on MSDN and greenbytes.de. However, SSL connections do bring improved security.

section.para:
Perform the following steps in Internet Explorer:
Select File -> Open.
Fill in URL like http://localhost:8080/exist/webdav/db/ or https://localhost:8443/exist/webdav/db/.
Check "Open as Web Folder".
Click OK.

section.title: Windows XP's My Network Places
section.para: This enables you to access eXist from almost any Windows XP application that supports 'Network Places' in the standard File dialog:
First, go to "My Network Places", click "Add..."
Then enter the eXist WebDAV URL, e.g. http://localhost:8080/exist/webdav/db/.
Finally click on the icon to access eXist.

section.title: Mac OS X Finder
section.para: The eXist database can be accessed easily with the Mac OS X Finder. First select in the Finder "Go" and "Connect to Server..."
Fill in the eXist WebDAV URL http://localhost:8080/exist/webdav/db/

note.para: Note on SSL connections in oXygen: You may encounter an error: "Error: sun.security.validator.ValidatorException: PKIX path building failed: sun.security.provider.certpath.SunCertPathBuilderException: unable to find valid certification path to requested target."
In order to avoid this error, you'll need to add the Server certificate to your trusted certificates keystore (more info).

Warning: When saving a document to the WebDAV server via oXygen, remember to double check that the document path in the File URL field at the top of the dialog does really contain the URL to which you want to save the document. It happens very easily that you click on another folder or resource by mistake and thus overwrite the wrong resource.

listitem.para: Enter Server URL without a slash on the end (otherwise you'll see 2x 'db')

section.title: KDE Konqueror
section.para: Enter an URL like webdav://localhost:8080/exist/webdav/db. Use webdavs:// for WebDAV over SSL.

section.title: Reverting to the old WebDAV implementation
section.para: Before eXist version 1.4.1 a custom implementation was used. This implementation has been deprecated because it was not stable enough and many WebDAV clients could not connect to the server. Although not recommended, it is possible to switch back to the old implementation by modifying the WebDAV configuration entry in the file WEB-INF/controller-config.xml. Modify the line <forward pattern="/webdav/" servlet="milton"/> into <forward pattern="/webdav/" servlet="WebDAVServlet"/>.
